article: Our bachelor uncle who lived with us was a quiet, approachable man, much given to hunting and fishing. It was one of the great pleasures of our young life to _ him on his trips. I remember my first fishing trip as if it were but yesterday. I have been happy many times in my life, but never more strongly than when I received that first fishing-pole from my uncle's hand, and started off with him _ the woods and meadows.  My uncle, who knew by long _ where were the best places of pickerel , considerately placed me at the most favorable point. I threw out my line _ I had so often seen others, and waited _ for a bite. Nothing came of it. "Try again," said my uncle.  Suddenly the bait sank out of _ . "Now for it," I thought; "here is a fish at last." I made a strong pull, and brought up some weeds. Again and again I _ out my line with aching arms, and drew it back empty. I looked at my uncle appealingly. "Try once more ," he said. "We fishermen must have patience." www.ks5u.com Suddenly something pulled my line and _ off with it into deep water. Jerking it up, I saw a fine pickerel 46 _ in the sun. "Uncle!" I cried, looking back in uncontrollable _ , "I've got a fish!" "Not yet," said my uncle. As he spoke there was a splash in the water; the _ fish disappeared in the middle of the stream; my hook hung _ from the line. I had lost my _ .  "But remember, boy," he said, with his _ smile, "never boast of catching a fish until it is on dry ground. I've seen older folks doing that in more ways than one, and so making _ of themselves. It's no use boasting of anything until it's done, nor then either, for it _ for itself."  How often since I have been _ of the fish that I did not catch! When I hear people boasting of a work as yet undone, I call to mind that _ and the wise caution of my uncle: "Never boast of your fish before you catch it."
